hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Husain: He came as a delegation to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and he gave his wealth to him. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ granted him the waters of Adda at al-Marwah, and the water-channels of grasshoppers, which included al-Ma'azah, Usaybh, Ahwa, al-Thimad, and al-Sudairah. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ stipulated for Husain, in what he granted to him: 'Do not cut off my animal, or do not cut off my pasture, and do not sell my water.'

narrators.name: Muhriz ibn Wizr
narrators.full_name: Muhriz ibn Wizr ibn Imran ibn Shu'ayth ibn Asim ibn Husain

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Multiple unknown narrators (Muhriz, Wizr, Imran, Shu'ayth, Asim) with no clear biographical information
Use of anna (أَنَّ) transmission term in genealogical chain (Imran through Asim) introduces ambiguity about direct hearing
Generational gaps with multiple ancestors narrating in succession raises concerns about actual transmission vs. family genealogy
Only Muhammad ibn al-Muthanna and Husain (companion) are identifiable figures
Data integrity issue: narrator names in source data don't match the Arabic text clearly

potential_issues.issue: Multiple unknown narrators throughout the chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains at least five narrators (Muhriz, Wizr, Imran, Shu'ayth, Asim) who are not found in standard biographical dictionaries of hadith narrators, indicating they are either majhul (unknown) or the chain data may be corrupted

potential_issues.issue: Use of anna (أَنَّ) transmission terms in middle of chain
potential_issues.impact: The transition from direct terms (حَدَّثَنَا/حَدَّثَنِي) to indirect anna terms (أَنَّ) in the genealogical segment suggests these may be indirect or reported narratives rather than direct transmissions, creating potential disconnections

potential_issues.issue: Genealogical rather than traditional hadith transmission structure
potential_issues.impact: The chain appears to follow a father-to-son genealogical pattern (Husain > Asim > Shu'ayth > Imran > Wizr > Muhriz) which, while potentially valid, differs from standard hadith transmission methodology and raises questions about whether each generation actually transmitted the hadith

potential_issues.issue: Data quality concern with narrator identification
potential_issues.impact: The narrators_in_isnad field in the source data lists different names for the IDs than what appears in the text, suggesting possible data extraction or entry errors

Topics: Incident of Husain ibn Mushmit receiving grant of waters from the Prophet ﷺ
Conditions set by the Prophet ﷺ for use of granted properties
Prohibition of cutting off pasture and selling water

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: A Bedouin came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: 'By what do I know that you are a prophet?' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'If I call this palm frond from this palm tree, will you bear witness that I am the Messenger of Allah?' Then he called it, and it began to descend from the palm tree until it fell to the Prophet ﷺ. Then he said: 'Return,' and it returned. So the Bedouin became Muslim.

chainIssues: Chain begins with Da'if narrator Muhammad ibn Sa'id which affects overall reliability
Transmission terms shift from direct (حَدَّثَنَا) to indirect ('an) after first narrator

Simak ibn Harb is weak (Saduq) in his narrations
Sharik is Saduq, not of highest reliability grade

potential_issues.issue: Chain begins with Da'if narrator (Muhammad ibn Sa'id)
potential_issues.impact: The first narrator is classified as Da'if (weak), which significantly weakens the entire chain regardless of other narrators' reliability. Muhammad ibn Sa'id al-Yamami is not trusted for hadith narration by most scholars

potential_issues.issue: Indirect transmission terms after first narrator
potential_issues.impact: Sharik, Simak, and Abu Dhubyan all narrate using 'an (عَنْ), which is less direct than حَدَّثَنَا or سَمِعْتُ. While these narrators are generally reliable, the change from direct to indirect terms creates potential for unverified connections

potential_issues.issue: Simak ibn Harb is classified as Saduq with weak memory
potential_issues.impact: Simak is generally considered reliable (Saduq) but has been noted for weakness in hadith transmission and memory issues, which adds another layer of weakness to an already weak chain

potential_issues.issue: The Bedouin Miracle narrative appears in multiple sources
potential_issues.impact: While this narrative is attested in other collections, this particular chain through Muhammad ibn Sa'id is problematic. Other versions may have stronger chains

Topics: Incident of the Bedouin asking for a sign from the Prophet ﷺ
The Palm Frond Miracle - descending and ascending at the Prophet's ﷺ command
Conversion of the Bedouin to Islam through witnessing the miracle

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Hayan: Abd al-Warith narrated to us, Muhammad ibn al-Zubayr narrated to us, Yazid ibn Husain ibn Numayr narrated to us, from his father, saying: 'I witnessed Bilal making a khutbah on behalf of his brother, while Umar had appointed him as governor of al-Urdunn, and they married him to an Arab woman. And it is said that he was among those who burned the Kaaba, though the chain is not sound.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman ibn Husain: Ibn Umar met Husain ibn Aws (or Ays) while I was with him, and said: 'O Abu al-Hakam, how many do you count these?' He replied: 'Seventy and some.' Then he wept and said: 'Between us and a hundred is only twenty-seven years.' And it is also said: Husain ibn Wais
